image-plane-coordinate-not-at-principal-.text: Image plane coordinate not at principal center

camera-center-not-at-the-origin-of-world.text: Camera center not at the origin of world coordinate

pageProps.body:
Pinhole Camera Model

Base case

Reference: http://www.songho.ca/opengl/gl_projectionmatrix.html

Begin with the assumption that

  • Camera with its center ccc placed at orgin and focal length in pixel fff
  • Image plane coordinate origin is the principal point
  • World coordinate and Image coordinate are evenly scaled along all axis

Under square pixel assumption, focal length in pixel=camera frame width∗focal length in mm/sensor width in mm\text{focal length in pixel} = \text{camera frame width} * \text{focal length in mm} / \text{sensor width in mm}focal length in pixel=camera frame width∗focal length in mm/sensor width in mm

For a point X=(X,Y,Z)T\bm{X} = (X, Y, Z)^TX=(X,Y,Z)T and it projection on image plane x=(x,y)T\bm{x} = (x, y)^Tx=(x,y)T

As is shown in figure, we have

fZ=xX=yY\frac{f}{Z} = \frac{x}{X} = \frac{y}{Y}Zf​=Xx​=Yy​
∴{x=fXZy=fYZ\therefore \begin{cases} x = \frac{fX}{Z} \\ y = \frac{fY}{Z} \end{cases}∴{x=ZfX​y=ZfY​​

The projection matrix P\bm{P}P is the one that transforms X=(X,Y,Z)T\bm{X} = (X, Y, Z)^TX=(X,Y,Z)T to x=(x,y)T=(fXZ,fYZ)T\bm{x} = (x, y)^T = (\frac{fX}{Z}, \frac{fY}{Z})^Tx=(x,y)T=(ZfX​,ZfY​)T

[xy1]=[fXZfYZ1]=[fXfYZ]=[f0000f000010][XYZ1]\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{fX}{Z} \\ \frac{fY}{Z} \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} fX \\ fY \\ Z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} f & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & f & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} X \\ Y \\ Z \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​xy1​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​ZfX​ZfY​1​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​fXfYZ​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​f00​0f0​001​000​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​XYZ1​⎦⎤​

Under the assumption that projection center is at origin, all points (X,Y,Z,T)T(X, Y, Z, T)^T(X,Y,Z,T)T with fixed XXX, YYY, ZZZ and varing TTT forms a ray, which all project to image point (fX,fY,Z)(fX, fY, Z)(fX,fY,Z), regardless of TTT.

Image plane coordinate not at principal center

Assume principal point offset w.r.t. image plane coordinate is (px,py)(p_x, p_y)(px​,py​)

Similar as before, but with x=(x,y)T=(fXZ+px,fYZ+py)T\bm{x} = (x, y)^T = (\frac{fX}{Z} + p_x, \frac{fY}{Z} + p_y)^Tx=(x,y)T=(ZfX​+px​,ZfY​+py​)T

[xy1]=[fXZ+pxfYZ+py1]=[fX+ZpxfY+ZpyZ]=[f0px00fpy00010][XYZ1]\begin{bmatrix} x \\ y \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \frac{fX}{Z} + p_x \\ \frac{fY}{Z} + p_y \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} fX + Zp_x \\ fY + Zp_y \\ Z \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} f & 0 & p_x & 0 \\ 0 & f & p_y & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} X \\ Y \\ Z \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}⎣⎡​xy1​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​ZfX​+px​ZfY​+py​1​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​fX+Zpx​fY+Zpy​Z​⎦⎤​=⎣⎡​f00​0f0​px​py​1​000​⎦⎤​⎣⎡​XYZ1​⎦⎤​

Camera center not at the origin of world coordinate

Assume the world transformation w.r.t. camera (TCW\bm{T}_{CW}TCW​) is [R∣t][\bm{R}|\bm{t}][R∣t]

We can then transform X\bm{X}X from world coordinate system to camera coordinate system (with camera center/projection center at origin) then apply the projective transformation

x=K[R∣t]X\bm{x} = \bm{K}[\bm{R}|\bm{t}]\bm{X}x=K[R∣t]X

K=[f0px0fpy001]\bm{K} = \begin{bmatrix} f & 0 & p_x \\ 0 & f & p_y \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}K=⎣⎡​f00​0f0​px​py​1​⎦⎤​ in camera intrinsic matrix, [R∣t]∈R3×4[\bm{R}|\bm{t}] \in \mathbb{R}^{3 \times 4}[R∣t]∈R3×4 is top 3 rows of the View Matrix

IMPORTANT View Matrix is the inverse of its Model Matrix, a.k.a. the camera's transform in world coordinate system

Non-square pixel

If the CMOS has non-square pixel, the image plane coordinate are not even scaled along xxx, yyy axis.

Denote focal lengths (in pixel) in xxx, yyy directions are fxf_xfx​, fyf_yfy​

K=[fx0px0fypy001]\bm{K} = \begin{bmatrix} f_x & 0 & p_x \\ 0 & f_y & p_y \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}K=⎣⎡​fx​00​0fy​0​px​py​1​⎦⎤​

Relation to field-of-view

As is illustrated in the figure

fovx=2arctan⁡(0.5∗wfx)fov_x = 2 \arctan (\frac{0.5 * w}{f_x})fovx​=2arctan(fx​0.5∗w​)
fovy=2arctan⁡(0.5∗hfy)fov_y = 2 \arctan (\frac{0.5 * h}{f_y})fovy​=2arctan(fy​0.5∗h​)

where www, hhh are image width, height

Change of image coordinate

Reference: https://dsp.stackexchange.com/questions/6055/how-does-resizing-an-image-affect-the-intrinsic-camera-matrix

Assume original K=[fx0px0fypy001]\bm{K} = \begin{bmatrix} f_x & 0 & p_x \\ 0 & f_y & p_y \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}K=⎣⎡​fx​00​0fy​0​px​py​1​⎦⎤​

Scaling example, (x,y)T→(ax,by)T(x, y)^T \to (ax, by)^T(x,y)T→(ax,by)T

Let scaling matrix S=[a000b0001]\bm{S} = \begin{bmatrix} a & 0 &0 \\ 0 & b & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}S=⎣⎡​a00​0b0​001​⎦⎤​

K′=SK=[fx/a0px/a0fy/bpy/b001]\bm{K'} = \bm{S} \bm{K} = \begin{bmatrix} f_x / a & 0 & p_x / a \\ 0 & f_y / b & p_y / b \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}K′=SK=⎣⎡​fx​/a00​0fy​/b0​px​/apy​/b1​⎦⎤​

In general, find a 3×33 \times 33×3 transformation matrix that transforms the image coordinate, then right multiply it with K\bm{K}K, a.k.a. apply the transformation

noteIndex.title: Root
noteIndex.body:
My personal knowledge cache using [Dendron](https://www.dendron.so)

## History
It was during my first job, at the start-up company called PixelShift.AI, that I acquired most prominent skill as a software engineer-the ability to read source code. It opened up a new way of learning and my knowledge expanded rapidly ever since. Learning new things is thriving but noting them down cogently and organized is hard. I often found myself forget the context few month later, making the notes completely intelligible. Additionally, some notes need frequent update as my previous understanding could be parochial, antiquated or even erroneous.

In desperate attempt to facilitate the noting/updating experience, I came across [Dendron](https://www.dendron.so) and found it surprisingly congenial to my personal need. With it, I have gradually grown the habit of caching, linking back and extending my knowledge base.

## Disclaimer
The notes are collections of information I found along the journey. I use backquote to denote sources, but I am likely to miss some references, so apology in advance. Also, they are my personal understandings, usually added when I first encounter the topic and will be updated only when I come across it again, so some of them could be incomplete or wrong.
